Manjunath Omana Kuttan

Research Interests

I find it exciting to work at the intersection of high energy physics theory and experiment.
My primary research focuses on both machine learning and non-machine learning approaches to analyze high-energy physics data. This includes everything from calibrating experimental data to developing AI twins of complex high-energy physics models, as well as tackling inverse problems in fundamental physics.

Specific areas of interest

  • Deep Learning (DL) Methods for Analyzing Experimental Data: Developing cutting-edge DL algorithms to analyze the complex datasets generated by HEP experiments. Currently focusing on high energy heavy-ion collision experiments.

  • Deep Learning to connect theory and experiments: Developing AI methods to extract theoretical, underlying physics information directly from raw experimental data in high enegy nucleus collisions.

  • DL and Bayesian Methods for Inverse Problems in Nuclear and Particle Physics: Combining DL and Bayesian inference techniques to solve inverse problems, where experimental observables are used to deduce underlying physical processes and parameters. This is particularly valuable in high energy nuclear physics for understanding thefundamental properties of nulcear matter such as the EoS.

  • Artificial Intelligence (AI) for Fast Simulations of Heavy-Ion Collisions (HIC): Leveraging AI techniques to accelerate complex simulations of high-energy nuclear matter created in HIC experiments. Focusing on methods that can be easily adapted for any other HEP experiment or model simulations.

  • Properties, Evolution & Measurements of High-Density QCD Matter in HIC: Investigating the evolution of quantum chromodynamics (QCD) matter under high-density conditions, using both model calculations and detector simulations.
